title: IRC Archive for channel #xwiki on 20 February 2015 - XWiki
content:
<xwikibot> has joined #xwiki  
09:51 <lucaa> has joined #xwiki  
10:04 <Slashman> has joined #xwiki  
10:07 <cjd> has quit  
10:12 <cjd> has joined #xwiki  
10:39 <ClemensR> has joined #xwiki  
10:41 <Enygma`> has joined #xwiki  
12:57 <ClemensR> seems I broke the "quality checks" buils on jenkins, but I cannot see why ... mostly as ci.xwiki.org is not responding much ... sorry for that, but I guess I need a moment to fix it  
13:08 <vmassol> ok ClemensR  
13:14 <vmassol> ClemensR: cannot is in one word in English AFAIK ;)  
13:14 <vmassol> (in "This can not be reverted")  
13:15 <cjd> both are correct  
13:16 <cjd> USACorrect, don't ask me about UK  
13:16 <vmassol> it's not about correcteness caleb  
13:17 <vmassol> it's about what's the most used and what people will expect to see without blinking  
13:17 <vmassol> and I have never seen "this can not be deleted"  
13:17 <vmassol> so I dn't believe it's the most used form  
13:17 <ClemensR> ok, me updating it anyway  
13:18 <vmassol> cjd: am I wrong?  
13:18 <vmassol> quick not scientific search: http://www.googlefight.fr/index.php?word1=%22this+cannot%22&word2=%22this+can+not%22  
13:18 <cjd> Actually slightly more important than  'can not' v. 'cannot'  is the presence of a subject  
13:19 <cjd> This action cannot be reverted  
13:19 <vmassol> yes better indeed  
13:19 <cjd> or this action can not be reverted, indeed cannot seems a tiny bit more natural  
13:20 <cjd> maybe something about USAnglais, lots of forms are considered good enough and we tend to get very good at interpreting meaning even without knowing it  
13:21 <ClemensR> interstingly we also have "platform.wiki.currentwiki.invitationCancelFailure=Error, you can not cancel this invitation." .. should I update this, too ?  
13:21 <cjd> haha, that's one which I wrote myself without any input  
13:21 <vmassol> me talk english too :)  
13:22 <cjd> b/c I wrote the invitation app  
13:22 <vmassol> is that USAnglais ;)  
13:22 <vmassol> ClemensR: yes you could update it too  
13:22 <cjd> well it's interesting because it came from me without any suggestion to skew my mind  
13:23 <cjd> platform.wiki.currentwiki.invitationCancelFailure=Error, this invitation cannot be cancelled.    <-- most correct IMO  
13:23 <ClemensR> ok, doing so, and then have to update screenshots, sigh, how this is the only chnage ;)  
13:23 <vmassol> personally it's hard for me to process "you can not cancel …" because I read "you can" then I have to read the "not" and revert what I was thinking ;)  
13:24 <cjd> \*shrug\* to me this is to the point of pediantry, English just isn't that strict  
13:24 <cjd> at least in the US  
13:25 <vmassol> it's like code styling  
13:25 <vmassol> it's important when you wish to share your code  
13:25 <vmassol> (share= have others work on it)  
13:26 <vmassol> ClemensR: thanks again for working on this important issue, it's great that we've now more protection against mistakes :)  
13:27 <ClemensR> thanks ... just still need to finish the last bits ;)  thanks for proofreading, in any case  
13:28 <vmassol> it's nice to see how relatively evenly we're participating to the BFD :) http://jira.xwiki.org/secure/Dashboard.jspa?selectPageId=10352#Pie-Chart/13614  
13:29 <vmassol> (for the top 5-6)  
13:29 <ClemensR> ah, and that invitation text is in another WikiManager.Translations, that one for the sub wikis ... I just stared at the code and could not find it :D  
13:42 <ClemensR> ah, seems jenkins is more complaining about  https://github.com/xwiki/xwiki-platform/commit/4a9a96b435085d69186a7915256bc12991c07e16 instead ?  
13:42 <ClemensR> asks for minimal better test coverage there ....  
15:00 <gsmeria> has quit  
15:03 <gsmeria> has joined #xwiki  
15:17 <gsmeria> has quit  
15:33 <evalica> does anyone know why on the latest snapshot we have "org.xwiki.rendering.macro.MacroExecutionException: Nested scripts are not allowed

17:40 <vmassol> guys, anyone know if these translation props https://gist.github.com/vmassol/031d3b34e4da6c8c4723 are used anymore? I couldn't find any reference by searching in the code base.
